What Will (Future) Christians Say About Us

John Thomas
Mar 30

In his book The Great Stain: Witnessing American Slavery, Noel Rae cites Genesis 9:18–27 and Ephesians 6:5–7 as two of the favorite passages Christian slaveholders used to justify slavery. Rae goes on to write, “…if asked, most slaveholders would have defined themselves as Christian.”

In 1553, Spanish theologian and physician Michael Servetus was burned at the stake in Geneva, Switzerland. His crime was heresy (Servetus rejected the idea of the trinity). Because John Calvin wielded much power in Geneva at the time of Servetus’s execution, and in fact agreed with his being put to death, many see this as a black mark on Calvin’s record as a believer and theologian.

These are just two examples, one of an individual Christian, the other of a group of Christians believing and behaving in a way that for us as followers of Christ today, at the very least makes us scratch our heads, and in some cases causes us to question the authenticity of their salvation. Though we are taught not to judge the past based on today’s standards and norms, these atrocities are hard to overlook.

But rather than debate the salvation status of men and women long since passed, let’s consider using these two unfortunate examples and many others that exist in the history of Christianity, to spur us on to check ourselves. “Examine yourselves, to see whether you are in the faith. Test yourselves. Or do you not realize this about yourselves, that Jesus Christ is in you? Unless indeed you fail to meet the test.” 2 Corinthians 13:5.

100 Years From Now

Not every era in Christian history is marred with such extreme examples of duplicity as the ages of slavery in America and the burning of heretics in Europe. But it would be extremely arrogant of Christians today, i.e. ourselves to think that we are living perfectly. I am not suggesting that anything Christians are involved in today is as revolting as the two previous examples (at least nothing on that wide of a scale comes to mind). We as believers, though Christ lives in us, can still be prone to spiritual blind spots. If Christ doesn’t return by then, what will Christians a hundred years from now say about us, the choices we made and the way we lived out our faith? By asking this question and examining ourselves we are taking a good first step. But what else can we do to be on guard against spiritual blind spots?

Read, Pray, Talk

After asking ourselves if we have any spiritual blind spots we need to know where to go to find the answer. “All Scripture is breathed out by God and profitable for teaching, for reproof, for correction, and for training in righteousness, that the man of God may be complete, equipped for every good work.” 2 Timothy 3:16–17. Perhaps the second most famous 3:16 verse tells us not only that we can rely on God’s word to be true, but that we will benefit from reading it. If we have a spiritual blind spot, reading God’s word is one way to find it out. As we are reading we can gauge our actions and our beliefs to see if they are in line with the thrusts and themes that are found in the Bible.

Reading the Bible alone though, might not be enough for us to rid ourselves of spiritual blind spots. As cited above Christian slaveholders used God’s word to justify their ownership and horrendous treatment of slaves. Unfortunately, our internal biases can cloud our minds when reading scripture and in some cases cause us to misinterpret a verse or even go in search of passages to reinforce ideas we hold to be true.

To help with this, reading books by authors from a variety of theological, philosophical and even political backgrounds can be useful. In my own life I have read and learned from John Piper as well as Shane Claiborne. In the last few years of my life perhaps nothing outside of scripture has shaped my life and views as much as David Platt’s Radical and Timothy Keller’s Generous Justice. At the same time Chinua Achebe’s novel Things Fall Apart has left a lasting impression on me. I don’t agree with everything I’ve read, but by reading widely I can identify gaps in the author’s reasoning and beliefs, and perhaps my own.

After reading, the next thing we need to do is pray. As we all know, prayer is an essential part of our relationship with our Father. If we detach ourselves from our convictions and pray as Jesus did in the garden, “…not what I will, but what you will,” Mark 14:36, the Holy Spirit will be faithful in showing us where we are out of step with the gospel. This prayer can be as it often was for Jesus, alone with our Father in a quiet place, or it can be corporate prayer seeking God’s will for our lives, our nation.

Finally, what we learn about ourselves and our worldviews when examining them through God’s word and through prayer might lead us to a place where we feel that we need to process what the Lord has been revealing to us with others. Bear one another’s burdens, and so fulfill the law of Christ.” Galatians 6:2. Though moving our hearts from spiritual blind spot into the light might be freeing and feel like a burden being released, translating that into action can feel daunting. Talking about what the Lord is doing in our hearts with faithful brothers or sisters can be helpful on the journey to overcoming a spiritual blindspot.

Ponderings

Abortion, gay marriage, guns, climate change, immigration, racism our nation has no shortage of divisive issues and we would do well to examine, read, pray, and talk about where we land on those issues. These are in no way predictions or prophecies, rather they are merely ponderings I have asked myself in the process of examining how Christians in the future might view my beliefs and actions: Will an abortion culture prevail? Is being a single issue voter a good idea? Wasn’t Jesus’ love inclusive? Wasn’t Jesus clear about marriage in Matthew 19? Is a culture of gun ownership consistent with turning the other cheek? If climate change is as bad as predicted is owning two cars the best idea? How can I reconcile building a wall when Jesus tore down the wall of hostility? Aren’t those who look different from me made in the image of God too?

Ultimately it is God who will judge us and not Christians living 100 years from now. But if we learn from the mistakes of the past, try to anticipate what future Christians might find lacking in the practice of our faith, and examine ourselves by reading, praying and discussing these things among faithful brothers and sisters, maybe we can avoid the kinds of spiritual blind spots that have caused so much pain in the past.

John Thomas (John_Thomas518) is a husband, father, writer, and global Christian. He currently lives in Central Asia with his wife and two children.
